text: Arbery was not “just jogging” and it wasn’t racially motivated gotta know your stuff first before you spit out wrong info. Do some a little research first🤡

answers.text: @janine.jn now nobody @ me anymore because this is a waste of my time. I hope your comments further the movement today

@jt78934 @claudleo Arbery was shot because to the killers, he looked like the man suspected in several break-ins. The house he ran into for a brief period of time was under construction. He engaged in no illegal activity and took nothing from the house. Now where do you think the sentiment lies in the saying “all _____ people look the same”. You really think the neighbours phone calls is substantial evidence? You want to believe the phone call of Amy Cooper who called the police on a black man saying he’s “threatening” her when he simply asked her to leash her dog? Do you not believe people can falsify statements for racially motivated reasons? Also you don’t think the killer’s Lawyers would have thought of portraying it from that angle? If you really believe so, explain to me your political stance on everything that’s ongoing rn and how OP’s comment serves to further that cause.

@claudleo since you wanna go into technicalities of my ~baseless comment~, so what if those claims were true about Arbery? Does it nullify his abuse? What about”complete” innocents like Sandra Bland, Tamir Rice, Michael Brown, etc. Making a comment like “🤡” does it sound like he is on the side of the original poster or not? This is called detracting and he could have phrased it better to prove his point since my phrasing so bothers you. Also, what is it with you people acting like only non-violent crime and innocents are worthy of speaking out on. Does someone who allegedly committed a crime deserve lynching to that degree too? I don’t know why detracting so is hard for people like you to understand

@claudleo At the moment, no political opinion is standalone due to the nature of what is going down in my country itself. Unfortunately every stance on this matter you put out, due to the overwhelming number of personal opinions that have been displayed by many individuals, ends up either on the side of the oppressor, or the oppressed. I didn’t even start out to be against the OP, I was baiting him to show what his actual stance was and he got upset instead of doing it. I don’t think there was anything wrong with my first comment. Also, I did not say he is not supportive of BLM. Look up detracting and you’d understand. I didn’t go into facts and bother proving OP wrong because I didn’t find it worth my time, he just sounded like another closed minded old man on the internet waiting to be made fun of

answers.text:
@xxr_29 Hi Xin Rong and ALL 35 OF YOU WHO LIKED HIS COMMENT, I strongly urge you to reflect and consider that your comment here is absolutely insensitive and uneducated.

I cannot think of a valid reason for all the people who are looting, but I strongly encourage you to consider that your comment is embarrassingly wrong. Please consider that this is a complicated matter and that the looting is not merely FOR George Floyd nor that material possessions are the reason for the looting. Perhaps not all of them, but these people are in PROTEST. and there is NO RIGHT WAY to protest.

In this case, I can see why you might have such a thought cross your mind. But just because something doesn't make sense or sit right with you, means it is wrong. Instead, you should ALWAYS research and find out more BEFORE forming (and ESPECIALLY SHARING) your opinions. In this case, perhaps I should remind yout that the media is something everyone should be extremely precautious about - I'm sure we all learnt that daily. 
On this note, I really also want you to reflect that perhaps your comment stems from a place of racism. Just perhaps.

My intention for calling you out is NOT to label/judge/one-up you - I just think that it is very dangerous (and honestly very embarrassing) for you to continue exercising such a pattern of thoughts and actions.

I hope you will take this message positively and move on from this to actively educate yourself and others (respectfully, please!) when in conversation/discussion about #blacklivesmatter and ANY topic of social injustice you encounter in your future for that matter. //Cheers. //- your fellow Singaporean Gen Z (@xxr_29 hey feel free to DM if you would like to continue this convo privately)

answers.text: @sleuth_zw people using this situation as an opportunity.

@sadboy.1993 You started off claiming you don’t get it either and you went off ranting about how the African American feel and their experience which in my previous response stated that you should not have your arguments from authority. Secondly what is ironic about condemning the murder of George Floyd and the looting and destruction of cities across the states? Thirdly, you made yourself look like the ignorant fool by suggesting that i should pick up a history book because historically peaceful demonstrations have not worked. Right back at you, MLK led the civil rights movement which leads to The Civil Right Act of 1964, which ended segregation in public places and banned employment discrimination on the basis of race, colour, religion, sex and or national origin, is considered one of the crowning legislative achievements of the civil rights movement. Hence you are in NO fucking position to lecture me for i view the situation and my historical knowledge.

@sleuth_zw except i don’t and haven’t claimed to “get it” either. i wouldn’t dare to claim to understand the african american experience bc i’m not african american and therefore cannot possibly understand what it feels like to be racially profiled and constantly at the mercy of the police. and exactly that’s why i’m pointing out your critique of the riots for stemming from a place of apathy and deference. as a non-black person you don’t know what it feels like to be raised wary of your own race and the dangers that surrounds being black. as a non-black person you don’t know what it feels like to have your recent history chock full of violence and hatred and disdain against your people. i don’t doubt your ability to think critically, but i doubt the integrity of your perspective simply because you’re making a ton of assumptions about what it means to be black and what experiences surround that. for instance, if you’re against the murder of george floyd - a murder which stems from racial bias and police integrity - isnt it also fucking ironic that you’re also against the riots that seek change and justice to prevent similar events from happening in the future..? if you’re against both of these events then what are you supporting? non-violent protests, i’m assuming? and here’s where you should go read a history book, because throughout the last several DECADES, african american people have been peacefully protesting for their right not to be racially profiled, and for their right to be treated equally by law enforcement. so how many more peaceful protests do you want them to hold and be ignored for? the violence that’s occurring now evidently a result of years and years of not injustice against them that has gone unheard and untreated. so for you to come and say that you “condemn the violence” serves literally no purpose besides supporting apathy and inaction. you are in NO fucking position to lecture people on how to protest.

@sadboy.1993 When u base your argument from authority you automatically made ur own arguement invalid. It is true i am not black, but guessing from that profile picture of yours i can tell u are not black living in the states. And how dare you criticise me of being apathetic, i condemn what has happen to George Floyd but i also condemn the violence, destruction and looting that has happen. Again you base your argument from authority, dosent mean i am not black i can’t think critically and i don’t have thought process and perspectives, for you to keep making the case that i am not black, hence, i wouldn’t get it or i am apathetic shuts down ur own argument.

@sleuth_zw you don’t get it because you live in singapore which has an outright ban on public demonstrations. i mean, ffs you’ve living in a society that supports being apathetic. a society that supports the act of deferring your grievances to govt bodies that may or may not do anything to help. this has only served to reinforce that apathetic singaporean mindset - a mindset that you clearly are very familiar with. how many peaceful protests is it going to take for black people to not get murdered bc of their race? an NFL player takes a kneel in solidarity with Black Lives Matter and it already invokes such a huge negative response. how many more black men are supposed to peacefully protest before their kids stop getting murdered..? have you been in a protest before? do you know anyone who has been in a protest before? no? then you wouldn’t understand.

@kateberly First of all, the officer was charged as 3rd degree murder which is as high as the judge could charge him. Secondly, name a institutional racism about the Police force so we can fight it together or else we are rioting for nothing.

@nxxdhx It’s not about replaceable or not replaceable, it’s about right or wrong. Yes, the officer messed up and the whole world condemns his action but there is no reason still to cause damage to members of your own community.

@sleuth_zw I haven’t been reading super extensively on the situation, but from what I’ve read, the riots in US are not only to raise the degree of his charge, but also to push for a reform of the police system in US. Before George Floyd there were a lot of cases of police brutality surfacing, and in the past month or so at least 3 major cases (George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor) or even more where they’ve been killed unnecessarily. The fact that policemen that killed them get off practically scot free, or (in Ahmaud Arbery’s case) the police only arrested the shooters after months is the reason why they are protesting. The main reason Derek Chauvin was prosecuted so quickly was because of how the story blew up online and everyone pushed for a charge.  The fact that people have been protesting for change since 2013 and have made barely any progress in legislation doesn’t help, and many of them are angry because of that. George Floyd’s case was merely the straw that broke the camel’s back.
@sleuth_zw are tou actually worried about something that is replaceable and not about lives that are lost that is actually not replaceable?

answers.text: @chris_loves_soup exactly. 5 black lives were already taken during this riot. Theyre literally protesting the murder of a black person by murdering more of them.
@chris_loves_soup then what do you expect them to do then
@chris_loves_soup chris, do you support the death penalty?

@the_state_of_nirvana not all internet debates end that way. I only wish all conflicts were resolved amicably without the need for violence but unfortunately I don't think it's the case. America has been riddled with oppression in various forms as is all societies including your own. I wonder why peaceful negotiations have yet been able to resolve such complex issues as institutional privilege.

@artifeystore i was talking about after the country was formed, and my goal wasnt to debate; rather just add information in the hopes of you maybe changing your view. I really dont like to argue or debate because nothing really ever comes of it but insults when someone has nothing left to result to.

@the_state_of_nirvana "small amount of oppression" I don't believe you know American or maybe even SEA history enough to have this debate my friend. America was founded on the basis of resisting the attempt by the British by virtue of the loyalists to impose British control.

@artifeystore the list can go on, those were cases in which the opressed gained their rights through peace. But yeah the list is rather short in america due to the age of the country and small amount of opression that really existed but if you look around the world there are many cases of opression being combatted through peace, those weren't exceptions.
@artifeystore If anything the rioters out there are the Domestic Terrorist

@the_state_of_nirvana your trivial pursuit at pointing to exceptions within a short span of history isn't proving anything. I understand that peaceful protests work, but this is not always the case. An oppressor seldom is willing to give up their ability to benefit from oppression on their own accord. Also anecdotedly, the majority of women opposed having the ability to cast their ballots during the era.

@chris_loves_soup violence has historically achieved many things, do not be fooled by liberal propaganda that tells you otherwise. To think violence is not an inherently human would be foolish and will leave you susceptible to be victimized. Why do we still have armies in an era where "violence" is not the answer?
@artifeystore womens marches for the 19th ammendment not ring a bell either?
@the_state_of_nirvana the exception is not the rule

@fhydsyh just because we're in singapore and live in a safe place, that does not mean we are not allowed to comment on external affairs. Violence is still violence, regardless of the rationale behind it. 
What can violence possibly hope to achieve? If anything it works against them, putting the blacks and other minorities in a bad light, making them out to be terrorists, criminals or savages because of their violent actions. Violence is not the answer, and I doubt it will change anything
@fhydsyh that doesn't mean violence is condonable
@artifeystore you're completely forgetting MLK
@fhydsyh preach
@chris_loves_soup You gotta fight fire with fire
@chris_loves_soup it's easy to say to protest peacefully when you are in sg safe and sound
@chris_loves_soup they protested by kneeling during the US national anthem before and they were still criticised. They protested peacefully before and not much has changed

@chris_loves_soup How has the world handled terrorist? Through peaceful negotiations? As history has shown us, pacifists do not create revolution or overthrow injustice. Not that I'm condoning violence, just an observation.

@chris_loves_soup yes but honestly idt think this is something for any of us here in singapore to comment about what they should or should not be given the fact that we didn’t and aren’t going through what they are, it’s very easy for us to sit here in a country where you don’t get killed for your race and dictate what they should or should not be doing, I’m not saying what you’re saying is wrong I mean rationally everyone can agree violence is bad but all I’m saying neither you nor me have been through what they have and every situation is diff you feel?

@chris_loves_soup complicated issue ah. it’s kinda like hong kong. the idea here is that so many people have been killed but nothing has been done so protestors have resulted to violence to make themselves heard
Resorting to violence only hurts their cause
